results.title: Maths for the 21st century
results.brief_description: This video says all the right things about maths and is entirely consistent with Frameworks. It has a Queensland focus (Teachers are a little passive compared to Victoria and the workshop style of Calvin Irons is certainly different). However, it should be a useful stimulus film for schools conducting their own self-help stimulus programs. The first sessions could be run over 5 weeks, hence its impact could develop as teachers progressively engage the ideas. No other credits available.

results.title: No labels for Annie
results.creator_credit: Stephen Skok and Healthsharing Women. Publishing and Production Group
results.brief_description: A portrait of Annette Duras, a young woman whose life has become enriched and meaningful since obtaining a job in “open employment”. The program highlights the need for us to resist categorising others with destructive labels and illustrates the positive effect on people when labels are discarded.

results.title: Zoo Dance
results.creator_credit: Tony Paice and Victoria. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: Dance movement programme operates at the Royal Melbourne Zoo. Its aims include encouraging creativity and communication between students and teachers, self-expression, building self confidence. Available to children with disabilities as well as the regular school student.

results.title: Staying alive show (episodes 1, 2 & 3)
results.creator_credit: Malcolm Orr, David Ferris, Lyndall Horton-Jones and Healthsharing Women. Publishing and Production Group
results.brief_description: An entertaining video which reinforces the traffic safety message for children in the early to middle primary years. Using the format of a popular TV game show, contestants are qizzed on the do’s and don’ts of pedestrian and passenger safety.

results.title: Frameworks in action: active learning
results.creator_credit: Chris O'Rourke and TV Ed Productions
results.brief_description: Three teachers show their approach to “active learning” in areas of primary English, postprimary Mathematics and Drama. This is part of a series showing teachers and parents practical responses to the Frameworks approach.

results.title: People people
results.brief_description: Designed to encourage excellence for people involved in customer service. It demonstrates how people in customer service can derive great personal satisfaction in their work by taking positive professional attitude to the people they are serving. Useful in the commerce frameworks area of Business Studies for Years 9 and 10. Also a valuable video for briefing students undergoing work experience in customer service related industry.

results.title: Pregnancy tape
results.brief_description: A video that attemps to answer all the major questions about pregnancy, chilbirth, and the initial uncertainty with the newborn child. Shows an actual birth.

results.title: Life of Galileo
results.creator_credit: David Zweck, Daryl Wayland and Country Education Project
results.brief_description: Peter Couchman and Dr Ray Misson discuss the social and moral questions implied in Bertold Brecht’s play “Life of Galileo”. Shows conflict with the church and the intellectual freedom of the individual. The play also enables Brecht to comment on modern attitudes.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Zweck, Daryl Wayland and Country Education Project

results.title: Nature of justice
results.creator_credit: David Zweck, Daryl Wayland and Country Education Project
results.brief_description: Peter Couchman and a panel discuss the origin of the nature of justice, the jury system, the connection between the law and justice, injustice and examples of the individual and the law. Particular reference is made to “Last days of Socrates”, “A kindness cup”, “Breaker Morant”, and “The wife of Martin Guerre”. Part 2 (27min) is a continuation of Part 1. It also looks at the concept of Justice, the place of punishment in justice, the distintion between moral, legal and social justice.

results.title: More or less: a film about food
results.creator_credit: Lawrie Whittle, Paddy Stitt and Healthsharing Women. Publishing and Production Group
results.brief_description: Andrew Daddo outlines the “More or less” diet which is advocated by the Life Be In It campaign as a plan for eating for the “rest of your life”. By choosing carefully from the five basic food groups and eating more bread, cereals, fruit and vegetables, and less sugar, fat and salt, and exercising regularly, more children can became aware of the choices involved in planning a balanced diet.
